Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigating Controls on Temporal-spatial Heterogeneous Deformation Along a Transpressive Strike-slip Fault System: The Eastern Denali Fault Corner
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2,000 km long Denali Fault is a major active fault system in Alaska that bounds crustal blocks, which slide past each other in a horizontal fashion. The fault has a long and complicated history over the past 65 million years. Due to its complex and curved geometry, there are portions of the fault where the motion of the blocks is oblique to the fault trend resulting in the formation of basins and fold and thrust belts. In this project, a research team from Purdue University, Syracuse University, and the University of Alaska are studying a portion of this fault to better understand the factors that control how these crustal blocks deform. They are particularly interested in determining whether the strength of the blocks on opposite sides of the fault or the geometry of the fault controls deformation. There are many large active fault systems like the Denali around the world and it is important to understand how these behave since many are capable of generating significant earthquakes such as the 2002 magnitude 7.9 earthquake on the Denali Fault. Additional desired societal outcomes of the study include full participation underrepresented minorities in STEM through support of Native American students and researchers and outreach to Alaskan Native American communities plus development of a globally competitive STEM workforce through undergraduate and graduate student training.

Transitional zones between primarily strike-slip motion and oblique convergence are a common feature along strike-slip faults. Deformation along these transpressive faults is controlled in part by both the obliquity of the applied stress and fault geometry (variation in strike and dip), and rheologic contrasts across the faults on the lithospheric- and crustal-scale. These transpressive fault regions offer insight into how strain is accommodated and also how the broad zones defined by thrust belts and foreland basins evolve along strike-slip fault systems as crustal blocks are translated along regions of varying obliquity. The east-central Denali fault segment has a generally simple geometry of unvarying strike and dip for about 120 km, lies between two large composite terranes of contrasting strength, and has a documented history of vertical tectonics during the Cenozoic. Thus, it serves as a natural laboratory to study the affect of these two distinct boundary conditions on the history of deformation along this active strike-slip fault system. This project will examine the importance of fault geometry relative to contrasts in lithospheric strength across faults on the heterogeneity of deformation along the eastern corner of the Denali fault. The Denali fault in this region changes from dominantly strike-slip to a transpressive regime. The competing hypotheses (strength vs. geometry) on how strain is accommodated and deformation occurs along this transpressive fault system will be tested by integrating thermochronology, geochronology, structural, and basin analysis studies. Detrital (modern river sediment and from strata) and bedrock thermochronology (K-feldspar 40Ar/39Ar, apatite fission-track and apatite (U-Th)/He) north and south of the Denali fault will track spatial and temporal patterns of exhumation in conjunction with basin development along the fault as proxies and recorders for deformational processes. 40Ar/39Ar and fission track tephrachronology, palynology, and vitrinite reflectance will delineate timing of basin subsidence, inversion, thermal history, and shortening rates. 40Ar/39Ar and U-Pb geochronology on clasts from conglomerate and sand samples will provide insight into paleo-drainage patterns and displacement of sediment sources from basins along the fault. Together, these integrated data will yield important new constraints on the relative contributions two common boundary conditions play in heterogeneous deformation patterns along a continental strike-slip fault system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This multi-year project set out to examine the importance of fault geometry relative to contrasts in lithospheric strength across faults on the heterogeneity of deformation along large-scale transpressional fault systems, using the eastern corner of the Denali fault as a study area. Strike-slip faults have bends, kinks, and straight segments which can lead to deformation being partitioned into horizontal slip and vertical movement depending on the obliquity of the applied stress. Strike-slip faults may also be the boundary between blocks of crust that have distinct geologic histories and rock types that result in strength contrasts across the fault. Such is the case along the Denali fault, and we applied mapping of rock units, structural mapping, basin analysis along with geochronology and thermochronology to examine how strain is accommodated and deformation occurs along a 120 km segment of the fault. Bedrock geochronology and thermochronology (whole rock and biotite 40Ar/39Ar, apatite fission-track and apatite (U-Th)/He) north and south of the Denali fault was used to track spatial and temporal patterns of exhumation and magmatism in conjunction with basin development along the fault as proxies and recorders for deformational processes. 40Ar/39Ar tephrachronology, palynology, and vitrinite reflectance provided important constraints for delineating timing of basin subsidence-inversion, thermal history, and shortening rates. 40Ar/39Ar and U-Pb geochronology on clasts from conglomerate and sand samples provided insight into paleo-drainage patterns and displacement of sediment sources from basins along this segment of the Denali fault.

We found that deformation south of this segment of Denali Fault is controlled largely by the convergence angle of the incoming plate relative to the strike of the fault segment. South of the fault deformation and associated mountain building (max elevation 2300 meters) is focused within 10 kms of the master strand of the Denali Fault. In this region a general southward propagation of a fold and thrust belt resulted in Oligocene and Miocene basin inversion and sediment recycling. North of this segment of the Denali Fault deformation occurs in a relatively weaker geologic terrane, in essence deforming against a much stronger geologic terrane south of the Denali fault. North of the fault deformation and associated mountain building (max elevation 3100 meters) is more distributed and occurs within 40 kms of the master strand of the Denali Fault. This is in part due to the relatively fixed nature of geologic terrane north of the fault, whereas the crustal block south of this segment has been translated ~80 km westward, into this region of focused deformation, in the last ~6 million years. Our research also provided additional constraints on the offset history of the Denali Fault, with results suggesting a minimum of ~400 km Denali Fault system offset since ~50 million years ago, ~300 km since ~25 million years ago, and 80 km of offset since ~6 million years ago.

Basin analysis complimented by tephra geochronology documents four distinct stages of Cenozoic basin development for the region south of the eastern corner of the Denali fault: 1) ~30 - 20 Ma:  fluvial- and alluvial fan-dominated depositional environments.  One tephra bed has been documented in this facies association; 2) ~6 - 5 Ma: lacustine and paludal depositional environments characterized this stage; numerous tephras occur near the top of this facies association; 3) ~5 Ma to present: the region has been translated onto a transpressive segment of the Denali Fault and deposition has been primarily by proximal alluvial fan and glacial environments. 4) Since ~2 Ma older basins have been inverted and exposed in thrust sheets with modern braided stream and glacial outwash deposition occurring more than ~10 km from the master strand of the Denali Fault. We infer both large-scale, plate boundary tectonic events (e.g. change in velocity and obliquity of convergence between the Pacific-Yakutat microplate and overriding North America plates at ~25 Ma and ~6 Ma) and the translation of crustal block through geometric complexities are responsible for the variations in depositional environments and inversion of basins. These plate boundary tectonic events were also associated with increases in magmatism demonstrated by the tephra deposits.

This project so far has resulted in five master’s degrees (including one by a Native American female student) and numerous conference abstracts, published manuscripts, and additional manuscripts in preparation. Parts of the isotopic tephra aspect of this work along with palynology results has assisted with ongoing regional paleoclimate reconstruction endeavors. Detailed geological maps were also constructed for the region of study south of the Denali Fault. Graduate and undergraduate students received STEM training, including field experience. An art exhibition of field photography took place in Fairbanks, Alaska and facilitated communication of the results of the project to the public.
